head.title: It Takes a Skeptic to Ignore Global Warming

hedline.hl1: It Takes a Skeptic to Ignore Global Warming

block.p: Your profile of Dr. Richard S. Lindzen of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (Science Times, June 18) misses some reasons he is isolated in his assessment that global warming will be of little significance.

Your profile of Dr. Richard S. Lindzen of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (Science Times, June 18) misses some reasons he is isolated in his assessment that global warming will be of little significance.

Dr. Lindzen says that the warming due to a doubling of carbon dioxide alone, with other factors like atmospheric water vapor held constant, would be only about 1 degree Fahrenheit, which he says would be of little consequence. In fact, this warming is known to an accuracy of about 10 percent to be 2.2 degrees Fahrenheit, a change that could produce the fastest global warming since the development of civilization.

You report that this "presumed amplifying effect" of water vapor is "built into the computer models." It is not. The models "reflect the physics" of water vapor to the best of our understanding. This physics includes Dr. Lindzen's "nullifying" processes, but these are overwhelmed by amplifying processes that he ignores.
The magnitude of water vapor's effect is uncertain, but not the direction in which it drives the climate. Precise satellite monitoring with available technology would help narrow this uncertainty.

Dr. Lindzen argues that the climate response to volcanic eruptions supports his assertion of very low sensitivity of climate to the buildup of greenhouse gases. But research at the Goddard Institute of Space Studies on the climate response to the eruption in 1991 of Mount Pinatubo, the only eruption studied in detail, supports the range of climate sensitivity reported by computer models, 3 to 8 degrees Fahrenheit, rather than Dr. Lindzen's estimate.

If there is little evidence to support Dr. Lindzen's scientific claims, there is even less to support his assertion that a bandwagon effect supported by a desire to obtain research grants is behind the greenhouse concern. Indeed, the National Academy of Sciences issued a report in 1992 with the following lead recommendation: "Despite the great uncertainties, greenhouse warming is a potential threat sufficient to justify action now."

ANTHONY DEL GENIO ANDREW LACIS MICHAEL OPPENHEIMER New York, June 19, 1996 The writers are, respectively, physical scientists at the Goddard Institute for Space Studies and chief scientist at the Environmental Defense Fund.
